Subject: Advisory on false Smut of rice caused by Ustiloginoidea virens- regarding

Dear Sir,

This has come to the knowledge of the Directorate that False Smut in rice commonly
known as Kandwa Disease of Rice was reported in Santkabir, Basti, Siddhartha Nagar,
Gorakhpur, Maharajganj, Kushinagar, Devaria and Ayodhya district of U.P in the year 2020-
21. It is imperative to conduct sensitization programme among farmers for management of
false smut of Rice to avoid re-occurrence of disease in next rice growing season. As primary
source of inoculums for false smut is soil, alternate host or contaminated seed, so it is highly
desirable to ensure inclusion of topics on management of false smut of rice in Farmers Field
School (FFS) and other farmers training programmes conducted by state agriculture
department of the ongoing season also and necessary preparation for management of disease

during ensuing rice growing season.
Further, it is requested that whenever FFS and other training programmes are being
conducted by the State Agriculture Department may kindly be brought to the knowledge of

RCIPMC, Lucknow.

Disease Cycle and Epidemiology

The disease can occur in areas with high relative humidity (>90%), temperature
ranging from 25—35 °C and moderate rainfall well distributed during the period of flowering.
Soil with high nitrogen content also favors disease development. Wind can spread the fungal
spores from plant to plant.

Nursery/seedling stage to transplanting stage

v

M

v

Keep the field clean, remove infected seeds, panicles, plant debris after harvest and
removal of alternate host.

Crop rotation with non host crops, it provides a mechanism that separates viable
spores in crop residue from the newly emerging seedlings

Use high quality disease free certified seeds. Seeds contaminated with fungal spore
may serve as inoculum for further spread and development.

Soil with high nitrogen content also favors disease development. Wind can spread the fungal
spores from plant to plant.

Crop rotation with non host crops, it provides a mechanism that separates viable
spores in crop residue from the newly emerging seedlings

Use high quality disease free certified seeds. Seeds contaminated with fungal spore
may serve as inoculum for further spread and development.

Early planted crop has less smut ball than the late planted crop

Hot water treatment of seeds at 52°C for 10 mins

Treat the seeds with Pseudomonas fluorescence 10g/lit of water for 30 minutes or
Trichoderma viridae @5-10 g/kg of seeds gives protection soil borne and seed
borne diseases.

Dip the seedlings in with Pseudomonas fluorescence Sg/lit of water for 20 minutes
before transplanting. Pseudomonas suppresses the diseases and also acts as plant
growth promotion and reduces the severity of many diseases.

Apply neem cake @150 kg/ha

Balanced use of fertilizers and micro-nutrients as per local recommendations.
Reduce humidity levels through alternate wetting and drying of fields rather than
permanently flooding the fields.

days after transplanting

Advisory on the management of false smut of rice
(Causal organism: Fungi- Ustiloginoidea virens)

False smut of rice was reported in Santkabir, Basti, Siddhartha Nagar, Gorakhpur,
Maharajganj, Kushinagar, Devaria and Ayodhya district of U.P in the year 2019-20 in
significant level, therefore, has potential to cause significant damage in 2021-22 Kharif
season also in the above mentioned area and may further spread in other rice growing areas
of states under favorable weather conditions. The disease occur in areas with high relative
humidity (©90%) and temperature ranging from 25-35 °C. Rain, high humidity, and soils
with high nitrogen content also favors disease development & wind can spread the fungal
spores from plant to plant. Primary source of inoculums is soil, alternate host or

contaminated seeds.

Keeping in view of the above, it is advised that the all rice growing areas of Uttar
Pradesh states may be intensively monitored during Rapid Roving Survey. Strong linkage
among State Agriculture Department, State Agricultural University, ICAR Institutes and
farmers to implement Integrated Pest Management (IPM) at village level need to be
developed. The following practices of IPM strategies may be followed for management of

false smut on Rice crop

Symptoms

False smut is visible only after panicle exertion. It can infect the plant during
flowering stage. Plants infected with false smut have individual rice grain transformed into a
mass of spore balls. These spore balls are initially orange, and then turn into greenish black
when these mature. In most cases, only few grains in a panicle are usually infected and the

rest are normal.

 

Orange coloured spore ball Mature black spore balls

Sub: Advisory on incidence of Gundhi Bug (Leptocorisa acuta) on rice- reg.

Sir,

Leptocorisa acuta (Rice Gundhi Bugs) damag

e rice by sucking out the contents of developing

grains from pre-flowering spikelets to soft dough stage, therefore causing unfilled or empty grains and

discoloration. Immature and adult rice bugs bo

th feed on rice grains. This is a pest of national

significance. The population of the rice gundhi bug increases at the end of the rainy season and found in

all rice environments. They are more common

milky stages of the rice crop.

This pest may cause serious damage to rice i
of this bug is 5 bugs/100 ear heads at flowering an

in rainfed and upland rice and prefer the flowering to

f proper management strategy not applied. The ETL
d 16 bugs/100 ear heads from milky stage to grain
 
 

 

5.

maturity. Therefore, it is requested to take all possible precautionary measures to minimize the effect of
Rice Gundhi bug (Leptocorisa acuta).

The following strategies are suggested to contain and suppress the Rice Gundhi Bugs:

e Strict vigilance is necessary at milky stage.
e Keep the field and bunds free of weeds and grasses.
e Conservation of meadow grasshoppers, spiders, coccinellid beetles and dragonflies.
e Putting attractants with an odor like dead snails or rats can easily capture rice bugs in the field.
e Use of formulation of 10% sweet flag (Acorus calamus) rhizome powder and 90% of fly ash dust.
e Use the following botanicals:
Neem (Azadirachta indica) seed kernel extract 5%
Notchi (Vitex negundo) leaf powder extract 5%
Pink morning glory (pomoea carnea) leaf powder extract 5%
Prosopis (Prosopis cineraria) leaf powder extract 5%

e Spray of 300ml of formulation of Imidacloprid 06% + Lambda-cyhalothrin 04% SL in 500
liter water. Waiting period is 10 days. Insecticides must be used as recommended by CIB&RC.

e IPM package of practices for rice need to be promoted. The IPM package of practices can be
down loaded from http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages/cereals.

e Use of formulation of 10% sweet flag (Acorus calamus) rhizome powder and 90% of fly ash dust.
e Use the following botanicals:
Neem (Azadirachta indica) seed kernel extract 5%
Notchi (Vitex negundo) leaf powder extract 5%
Pink morning glory (pomoea carnea) leaf powder extract 5%
Prosopis (Prosopis cineraria) leaf powder extract 5%

e Spray of 300ml of formulation of Imidacloprid 06% + Lambda-cyhalothrin 04% SL in 500
liter water. Waiting period is 10 days. Insecticides must be used as recommended by CIB&RC.

e IPM package of practices for rice need to be promoted. The IPM package of practices can be
down loaded from http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages/cereals.

The hot spots of Rice Gundhi Bug should be identified in pre-flowering spikelets stage and
undertake need based plant protection measures to avoid economic loss. Timely supply of quality
pesticides/ botanicals for the management of Rice Gundhi Bug on rice should be ensured.

In view of the above, it is requested to monitor the rice crop on regular basis and if major
incidence of Rice Gundhi Bug is reported by the farmers, extension functionaries and even through
_ newspapers or other sources, survey of the affected fields may be conducted immediately and the
concerned officials at the district/ division/ block may be advised to take the suitable plant protection
measures immediately. The detailed information may also be sent to the Directorate through email
ppa@nic.in urgently to apprise the same to Department of Agriculture, Cooperation & Farmers
Welfare.

Yours faithfully

(Dr.Ravi Praksh)
Plant Protection Adviser

Sub: Advisory for management of Rice Stem Borer (Scirpophaga incertulas) on rice crop
-reg.

Si,

It is to bring to your notice that incidence of Rice Stem Borer (Scirpophaga incertulas) on
rice crop is reported in the Maharashtra, Punjab and Haryana states. The pest was reported in
Gadchiroli districts of Maharashtra above ETL (Area affected 23599.24 ha) and Amritsar
district and SBS Nagar of Punjab at moderate level (Area affected 550 ha and 77 ha,
respectively) and Sonipat, Jind and Kaithal districts of Haryana at trace to low level. Keeping
in view the current crop stage and prevailing weather condition, Integrated Pest Management
techniques should be adopted. IPM Package of practices of Rice is available at DPPQ&S
website in the link https://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages. Important IPM for management of Rice
Stem Borer are listed below

Monitoring of field at weekly intervals/regularly

Handpick and destroy egg masses

Removal and destruction of diseased/pest infestedlant parts.

Field should be necessarily scouted during the vulnerable crop growth stages for early

detection of dead hearts and white ear.

5. Raise level of irrigation water periodically to submerge the eggs deposited on the lower
parts of the plant.

6. Installation of light trap @ l/ha and pheromone trap @ 10-12/ha for monitoring/
controlling adults.

7. Apply nitrogen fertilizer in split following the recommended rate and time of
application.

8. Avoid high dose fertilizer.

9. Five to six releases of the egg parasitoid Trichogramma japonicum or T chilonis @
1,00,000 adult parasites per hectare starting from 15 days after planting.

10. Encourage biological control agents: Tetrastichus schoenobii, Telenomus rowani,
Amauromorpha accepta, Cotesia flavipes, Xanthopimpla flavolineata, Pardosa
pseudoannulata (wolf spider) etc.

11. Recommended botanicals/ biopesticides should be used to manage the pest so as to

avoid it to reach to ETL

Sub: Advisory on Rice Swarming Caterpillar (Spodoptera mauritia) on rice crop -reg.
Sir;

I have the honor to bring to your notice that rice Swarming Caterpillar
(Spodoptera mauritia) or armyworm, a polyphagous pest infests various graminaceous
crops and weeds is reported to cause severe losses to rice crop especially in upland rice
from North East India. This pest emerged in epidemic form many times during last few
years. The swarming caterpillars damage the paddy crop by cutting off leaf tips, leaf
margins, leaves and even the plants at the base, more severely on the seedlings in nursery
and direct seeded crops and early tillering stage in transplanted rice. The grown up
caterpillars feed voraciously by night devouring the entire plant and hide during the day
time. Later in the season they migrate from older rice fields to grassy areas where
subsequent broods cause severe damage.

Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing favourable weather
conditions for the pest the rice crop should be monitored regularly for pest build up and
adopt Integrated Pest Management techniques. AESA based IPM Package of practices of
rice and pest specific package of practices of Rice Swarming Caterpillar are available at
DPPQ&S website in the link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages. Important IPM practices are
listed below

e Deep ploughing the field in summer exposes the larvae and pupae for predation by birds
Infested crop residues should be removed and destructed promptly.

e Flooding the nurseries and paddy fields bririgs out the larvae to the surface, which get
predated by the birds. Herd of ducks if let in to the field, will feeds on the caterpillars

e Farmers must be advised to maintain field sanitation at the vicinity of the main field
and nearby areas must be kept free from weeds.

Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing favourable weather
conditions for the pest the rice crop should be monitored regularly for pest build up and
adopt Integrated Pest Management techniques. AESA based IPM Package of practices of
rice and pest specific package of practices of Rice Swarming Caterpillar are available at
DPPQ&S website in the link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages. Important IPM practices are
listed below

e Deep ploughing the field in summer exposes the larvae and pupae for predation by birds
Infested crop residues should be removed and destructed promptly.

e Flooding the nurseries and paddy fields bririgs out the larvae to the surface, which get
predated by the birds. Herd of ducks if let in to the field, will feeds on the caterpillars

e Farmers must be advised to maintain field sanitation at the vicinity of the main field
and nearby areas must be kept free from weeds.

e In case of severe infestation, small plots can be isolated and the movement of the
caterpillars can be prevented by digging a trench around the infested field wherever
possible.

e kerosene oil may be poured into the stagnant water in the bunded fields (2 L kerosene per
hectare). With the use of a long rope stretched across the field (two persons walk through the
field) the paddy plants are shaken rigorously. The larvae fall into the kerosenized water and
ultimately die.

e As the moths of S. mauritia are attracted towards light, therefore, light traps can also be
utilized for mass trapping of the moths.

Sub: Advisory for management of Rice leaf folder (Cnaphalocrocis medinglis) on rice
crop. -reg.

Sit;

It is to bring to your notice that incidence of Rice leaf folder (Cnaphalocrocis medinalis)
on rice crop is reported in the Odisha, Punjab and Haryana region. The pest was reported in
Faridkot districts of Punjab, Cuttak and Dhrnkanal districts of Odisha and Sonipat district of
Haryana at moderate intensity (Area affected 2900 ha in Punjab). Keeping in view the current
crop stage and prevailing weather condition, Integrated Pest Management techniques should
be adopted. IPM Package of practices of Rice is available at DPPQ&S website in the link
https://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages. Important IPM for management of Rice Leaf Folder are
listed below

1. Low usage of nitrogenous fertilizers decreases a damage. Highly fertilized plots
seem to attract females for oviposition. Therefore, it is advisable to avoid over-
fertilization.

2. Egg predators (crickets) inhabit surrounding grass habitats and move to the field at night for
predation. Maintenance of non-rice habitats.

3. Higher damages will occur in shaded areas. Therefore, remove the causes of shading
within the field.

4. Removal and destruction of diseased/pest infested plant parts.

Use of coir rope in rice crop for dislodging leaf folder larvae etc. on to kerosinized

water (1 L of kerosene mixed on 25 kg soil and broadcast in |ha).

Remove grassy weeds from fields and borders.

Flood and plough field after harvesting if possible.

Rotate rice with a different crop, or have a fallow period.

Avoid ratooning

0. Encourage predators such as spider, parasitic wasps, predatory beetles, frogs and
dragon fly.

. Encourage biological control agents like Trichogramma japonicum and T chilonis may be
released @ 1 lakh/ha on appearance of egg masses / moth of leaf folder in the field, Egg
Parasitoid Copidosomopsis nacoleiae, Larval Parasitoid Stenobracon nicevillei, Larval and
Pupal Parasitoid Brachymeria lasus, B. excarinata etc.

Sub: Current status of Bacterial Leaf Blight (Xanthomonas campestris pv oryzae) at
Rice growing areas of Odisha-Advisory reg.

Sir,

I have the honour to bring your kind notice that incidence of Bacterial leaf blight
(Xanthomonas campestris pv oryzae) on Rice crop has been reported at Low to Moderate level
in Balianta and Balipatna blocks of Khorda district and Pipali block of Puri district of Odisha
state. Its incidence may further spread in other rice growing areas of state if favourable weather
conditions prevail.

Keeping in view of the severity of the pest, it is advised that the all rice growing areas
of Odisha state may be intensively monitored during Rapid Roving Survey for assessment of
infestation of Bacterial leaf blight. Therefore, strong linkage among State Agriculture
Department, State Agricultural University, ICAR Institutes and farmers to implement
Integrated Pest Management (IPM) at village level need to be developed.

The following practices of IPM strategies may be followed for management of Bacterial
Leaf Blight in Rice crop

1. Reduce nitrogen application and apply if needed only small dose of nitrogen in more split
doses, chemicals as recommended earlier.

2. Avoid field to field irrigation.

3. Farmers should be advised through extension functionaries to use only recommended doses
of fertilizers and pesticides as per approved label claims by CIB&RC.
 
Copy to:

A strong and foolproof quality control system for fertilizers, bio-fertilizers, pesticides needs
to be enforced.

Regular training programme for the extension workers, pesticide dealers and farmers should
organized by the SAUs/ICAR institutes/CIPMCs/ KVKs for up-gradation of their knowledge
and skill regarding management of Stem borer.

Insecticides must be used as per label claim approved by the Central Insecticides Board and
Registration Committee, Detailed information is available at http://ppqs.gov.in/divisions/cib-
rc/major-uses-of-pesticides However, list of recommended pesticides for Bacterial Leaf
Blight is attached. (Annexure-I)

IPM package of practices for rice need to be promoted. The IPM package of practise for rice

may be downloaded from web-link. http://ppqs.gov.in/sites/default/files/rice.pdf

In view of the above, it is advised to undertake monitoring of rice crop on regular basis
and if any more infestation of Bacterial leaf blight is reported by the farmers, extension
functionaries and even through the newspapers or other source, survey of the affected area
may be conducted immediately and the concerned officials at the Division/District/Block
may be advised to take suitable plant protection measures immediately. The detailed status
report may be sent to this Directorate through Fax (Nos. 0129-2412125 or 01 1-23384182) or
e-mail: ppa@nic.in or appa.ipm-ppq s@gov.in urgently to apprise Department of Agriculture,

Cooperation & Farmers Welfare. :

Sub: Advisory on Brown Plant Hopper (Nilaparvata lugens) on rice crop -reg.
Sir,

I have the honor to bring to your notice that Brown Plant hopper is the major pest in
rainfed and in irrigated wetland rice environments and also occurs in the areas with continuous
cultivation, submerged conditions in the fields, high shade, use of chemical fertilizers /pesticides
and humidity. It is a typical vascular feeder primarily sucking phloem sap leading to hopper burn.
At early infestation, circular yellow patches appear which soon turn brownish due to the drying up
of the plants. The patches of infestation then may spread out and cover the entire field. The grain
setting is also affected to a great extent. During sustained feeding, it excretes a large amount of
honeydew

Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing favourable weather
conditions for the pest the rice crop should be monitored regularly for pest build up and
adopt Integrated Pest Management techniques.

Sir,

I have the honor to bring to your notice that Brown Plant hopper is the major pest in
rainfed and in irrigated wetland rice environments and also occurs in the areas with continuous
cultivation, submerged conditions in the fields, high shade, use of chemical fertilizers /pesticides
and humidity. It is a typical vascular feeder primarily sucking phloem sap leading to hopper burn.
At early infestation, circular yellow patches appear which soon turn brownish due to the drying up
of the plants. The patches of infestation then may spread out and cover the entire field. The grain
setting is also affected to a great extent. During sustained feeding, it excretes a large amount of
honeydew

Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing favourable weather
conditions for the pest the rice crop should be monitored regularly for pest build up and
adopt Integrated Pest Management techniques. AESA based IPM Package of practices of
rice and pest specific package of practices of Brown Plant Hopper are available at
DPPQ&S website in the link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages. Important IPM practices are
listed below

e Maintain field sanitation. Main fields and bunds must be kept free from weeds which
harbour the BPH population.

e Synchronous planting (planting neighbouring fields within 3 weeks) in an area and
maintaining a rice free period is effective in BPH management.

e Alley formation after each 8 or 10 rows in edst-west direction in endemic areas helps i in
minimizing the population and provide congineal environment for BPH.

e Alternate wetting & drying the field in which the field should be atleast drained for 3-4
days when heavy infestations occur. This will reduce the infestation of BPH.

e Reduce the excess use of nitrogenous fertilizers. split application of nitrogenous fertilizer
along with split application of appropriate dose of potassium fertilizers should be followed to
reduce chances of plant hopper out breaks.

e In situ conservation and augmentation of natural enemies viz.,Egg parasitoid like Anagrus
oligosita spp, Larval parasitoids such as Haplogonatopus sp., Pseudogonatopus spp., Larval
and pupal parasitoids like Xanthopimpla flavolineata Brachymeria lasus, and Predators such as
Coccinellid beetles, Ground beetle, Rove beetle, Lynx spider, Long-jawed and Orb spider and
an important egg-feeding predator is the mirid bug, Cyrtorhinus lividipennisis.

e Use of neem oil @ 5 ml/L with 2 ml liquid detergent as spray covering both the foliage and the
base of the plants can act as an insect growth regulator and reduce the egg laying capacity of
females.

To be conlinyed
 
a €

e Extract of the Water Pepper leaf (Polygonum hydropiper) @ 20 gm/L with 2 ml liquid
detergent as an ITK can manage BPH effectively.

e If infestation is below ETL application of Bio-insecticides like 5% Neem seed kernel extract
(NSKE) or commercial neem formulation containing Azadirachtin1500 ppm @ 2.5ml/ litre of
water or Metarhizium anisopliae 1.15% WP with spore count of 1 x 108 cfu/gm (1 Kg/acre) @
2-5 g/litre may be applied aiming base of the plants.

e Pesticide must be used as per label claim’approval by the Registration Committee.

rce/major-uses-of-pesticides. Further the list of RC approved pesticides against BPH are

Sub: Current status of Stem borer (Scirpophaga incertulas) at Rice growing areas of
Uttar Pradesh-Advisory reg.

Sir,

I have the honour to bring your kind notice that incidence of stem borer (Scirpophaga
incertulas) on rice crop has been reported at Low to Moderate level in Nari, Gauhari, Borka
Bokhari, Jab chhoti, Bathan, Bari Bathan, Piparawala and Khadona villages and at Severe level
in Gauhari, Nari and Semali villages of Chhata block of Mathura district of Uttar Pradesh state.
Its incidence may further spread in other rice growing areas of State if favourable weather
conditions prevail.

Keeping in view of the severity of the pest, it is advised that the all rice growing areas
of Uttar Pradesh state may be intensively monitored during Rapid Roving Survey for
assessment of population of Stem borer. Therefore, strong linkage among State Agriculture
Department, State Agricultural University, ICAR Institutes and farmers to implement
Integrated Pest Management (IPM) at village level need to be developed.

The following practices of IPM strategies may be followed for management of Stem
borer on rice crop :

Farmers should be educated to identify, conserve and augment the natural enemies available
in the rice field viz., Parasitoids like Trichogramma spp., Tetrastichus schoenobii,
Telenomus rowani, Amauromorpha accepta, Cotesia flavipes, Bracon sp., Xanthopimpla
flavolineata, etc. and predators like Spiders etc.

Sub: Current status of Brown Plant Hopper (Nilaparvata lugens) at Rice growing areas of
Odisha, Uttar Pradesh and Chhattisgarh states -Advisory reg.

Sir,

I have the honour to bring your kind notice that incidence of Brown Plant Hopper
(BPH) on Rice crop has been reported at Low to Moderate level in Sambalpur district and at
Moderate to High level in Bargarh, Sonepur and Bolangir districts of Odisha state, Trace to
Moderate level in Maharajganj and Siddharthnagar districts of Uttar Pradesh state and Trace to
Moderate level in Berala and Bemetara block of Bemetara district and Dharsiwa block of
Raipur district of Chhattisgarh state. Its incidence may further spread in other rice growing
areas of states if favourable weather conditions prevail.

Keeping in view of the severity of the pest, it is advised that the all rice growing areas
of Odisha and Uttar Pradesh states may be intensively monitored during Rapid Roving Survey
for assessment of population of BPH. Therefore, strong linkage among State Agriculture
Department, State Agricultural University, ICAR Institutes and farmers to implement
Integrated Pest Management (IPM) at village level need to be developed.

The following practices of IPM strategies may be followed for management of Brown
Plant Hopper on Rice crop:

. Farmers must be educated to identify, conserve and augment the natural enemies available in
the rice fields. Such as egg parasitoids like Gonatocerus spp, Anagrus spp. Oligosita spp,
larval and pupal parasitoids such as Haplogonatopus sp, Pseudogonatopus spp. Predator
such as Coccinellid beetles, Carabid beetle, Rove beetle(Paederus fuscipes) and spiders like
Wolf spider, Lunx spider long jawed spider and Orb spider.

. High dosages of nitrogenous fertilizers, close spacing, and high relative humidity increases

plant hopper populations.

. Sensible use of fertilizer by splitting nitrogen applications can also reduce chances of plant

hopper outbreaks.
. Draining rice fields can be effective in reducing initial infestation levels. The field should be
drained for 3 - 4 days when heavy infestations occur.

. Farmers should be advised through extension functionaries to use only recommended doses

of fertilizers and pesticides as per approved label claims by CIB&RC.

. A strong and foolproof quality control system for fertilizers, bio-fertilizers, pesticides needs

. to be enforced.

. Regular training programme for the extension workers, pesticide dealers and farmers should
organized by the SAUs/ICAR institutes/CIPMCs/ KVKs for up-gradation of their knowledge
and skill regarding management of Stem borer.

.

. High dosages of nitrogenous fertilizers, close spacing, and high relative humidity increases

plant hopper populations.

. Sensible use of fertilizer by splitting nitrogen applications can also reduce chances of plant

hopper outbreaks.
. Draining rice fields can be effective in reducing initial infestation levels. The field should be
drained for 3 - 4 days when heavy infestations occur.

. Farmers should be advised through extension functionaries to use only recommended doses

of fertilizers and pesticides as per approved label claims by CIB&RC.

. A strong and foolproof quality control system for fertilizers, bio-fertilizers, pesticides needs

. to be enforced.

. Regular training programme for the extension workers, pesticide dealers and farmers should
organized by the SAUs/ICAR institutes/CIPMCs/ KVKs for up-gradation of their knowledge
and skill regarding management of Stem borer.

. Insecticides must be used as per label claim approved by the Central Wscclivices Board and

Registration Committee, Detailed information is available at http://ppqs.gov.in/divisions/cib-
rc/major-uses-of-pesticides However, list of recommended pesticides for Brown Plant
Hopper is attached. (Annexure-I)

. IPM package of practices for rice need to be promoted. The IPM package of practise for rice

may be downloaded from web-link. http://ppqs.gov.in/sites/default/files/rice.pdf

In view of the above, it is advised to undertake monitoring of rice crop on regular basis
and if any more incidence of Brown Plant Hopper is reported by the farmers, extension
functionaries and even through the newspapers or other source, survey of the affected area
may be conducted immediately and the concerned officials at the Division/District/Block
may be advised to take suitable plant protection measures immediately. The detailed status
report may be sent to this Directorate through Fax (Nos. 0129-2412125 or 011-23384182) or
e-mail: ppa@nic.in or appa.ipm-ppqs@gov.in urgently to apprise Department of Agriculture,
Cooperation & Farmers Welfare.

Sub: Current status of Rice Hispa (Dicladispa armigera) on Rice crop growing areas of
Assam state-Advisory reg.

Sir,

I have the honour to bring your kind notice that CIPMC-Guwahati conducted a special
survey during 16.08.2018 to 18.08.2018 at Kamrup, Nagaon, Sonitpur and North Lakhimpur
districts of Assam. The surveyed team found incidence of Hispa in Rice crop at Low to Moderate
in Khatarbari, Rahdhola, , Solengiri, Pukhuripara, Monapara and Kulabali villages and trace to
low in Bholaguri village of North Lakhimpur district.

Keeping in view of the severity of the pest, it is advised that the all rice growing areas of
Assam and neighbouring states may be intensively monitored during Rapid Roving Survey for
assessment of population of Rice Hispa. Therefore, \here is a need to develop strong linkage
among State Agriculture Department, State Agricultural University, ICAR Institutes and farmers
to implement Integrated Pest Management (IPM) at village level.

‘

The following practices of IPM strategies may be followed for management of Hispa on
rice crop

1, Sustained collection of adults by sweep net and destruction suppress populations and
reduces damage. ‘i

2. The removal of rice ratoons and volunteer rice during the crop-free season affects the rice
hispa’s survival and multiplication of over-wintering populations.

3. In situations of high hispa incidence, skip nitrogen fertilizer top-dressing. Note that top-
dressing after the pest is controlled can enhance recovery.

4. Conserve the natural predators, larval parasitoids viz., Bracon sp.

Sub: Advisory on blast disease (Magnaporthe oryzae) on rice crop -reg.
Sir,

1 have the honor to bring to your notice that Paddy blast is an important disease
which is responsible for significant yield losses in rice crop. This disease is caused by the
fungus Magnaporthe oryzae which can infect rice crop at all growth stages and all aerial
parts of the plant leaves, neck, nodes and seeds. Leaf and neck infections are more severe and
infection during seedling stage may cause severe damage to the crop. Rice blast is favored by low
temperatures (22-28°C), high relative humidity (+95%), dew deposits, leaf wetness for more than
10 hours, application of high nitrogen and aerobic soils.

Keeping in view the prevailing favourable weather conditions for the disease
development the rice crop should be monitored regularly for disease development and
adopt Integrated Disease Management techniques. AESA based IPM Package of practices
of rice and disease specific package of practices of rice blast are available at DPPQ&S
website in the link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages. Important IPM practices are listed
below

e Keep the field clean, remove infected seeds, panicles, and plant debris after harvest.

e Crop rotation with non host crops, it provides a mechanism that separates viable spores in
crop residue from the newly emerging seedlings

e Use high quality disease free certified seeds. Infected seeds may serve as inoculum
forfurther spread and development.

e Treat the seeds with Pseudomonas fluorescence 0.5% WP (TNAU Strain Accession No.
ITCC BE 0005) 10g/Kg of seed or Pseudomonas fluorescens 1.5% WP (BIL-331 Accession
No. MTCC5866) 5g/Kg of seed or Pseudomonas fluorescens 1.5% LF (MTCC no. 5671,
Strain designation Pf-1) 4.5 ml/Kg of seed gives protection soil borne and seed borne
diseases.

e Crop rotation with non host crops, it provides a mechanism that separates viable spores in
crop residue from the newly emerging seedlings

e Use high quality disease free certified seeds. Infected seeds may serve as inoculum
forfurther spread and development.

e Treat the seeds with Pseudomonas fluorescence 0.5% WP (TNAU Strain Accession No.
ITCC BE 0005) 10g/Kg of seed or Pseudomonas fluorescens 1.5% WP (BIL-331 Accession
No. MTCC5866) 5g/Kg of seed or Pseudomonas fluorescens 1.5% LF (MTCC no. 5671,
Strain designation Pf-1) 4.5 ml/Kg of seed gives protection soil borne and seed borne
diseases.

e Dip the seedlings in with Pseudomonas fluorescence 5g/lit of water for 20 minutes before
transplanting. Pseudomonas suppresses the diseases and also acts as plant growth promotion
and reduces the severity of many diseases.

e Broadcast 1 kg Pseudomonas fluorescens 0.5% WP (TNAU Strain Accession No. ITCC BE
0005) by mixing with 2.5 kg organic manure in one ha area

e Removal and destruction (burn) of diseased plant parts

e Maintaining a proper water level for the paddy to grow. Rice blast is known to be more
severe in fields or parts of fields in which the water in paddy falls below recommended
levels.

Sub: Advisory on thrips and whitefly of cotton crop -reg.

Sir,

It is to bring to your notice that incidence of thrips has been reported above Economic

threshold level (ETL) at Sri Muktsar Sahib District of Punjab and white fly incidence is reported
above ETL at Telupara village, Khuian Sarwar block of Fazilka district of Punjab during regular
surveys carried out by CIPMC Jalandhar. Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing

weather conditions Integrated Pest Management techniques should be adopted. Agro Ecosystem
Analysis (AESA) based IPM Package of practices of cotton are available at DPPQ&S website in the
link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages -Important IPM practices for management of thrips and cotton
are listed below

Regular pest surveillance on host crop including alternate hosts should be carried out for
timely management of thrips and whitefly.

Eradicate alternate weed hosts to check the multiplication of thrips and whitefly.

Balanced use of fertilizers & optimum use of irrigation for overall crop pest and disease
management.

Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing

weather conditions Integrated Pest Management techniques should be adopted. Agro Ecosystem
Analysis (AESA) based IPM Package of practices of cotton are available at DPPQ&S website in the
link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages -Important IPM practices for management of thrips and cotton
are listed below

Regular pest surveillance on host crop including alternate hosts should be carried out for
timely management of thrips and whitefly.

Eradicate alternate weed hosts to check the multiplication of thrips and whitefly.

Balanced use of fertilizers & optimum use of irrigation for overall crop pest and disease
management.

Farmers must be educated to identify, conserve and augment the natural enemies available in
the cotton fieids parasitoides like Eretmocerus mundus, Encarsia Jormosa and predators like
Spiders, Syrphid fly, Chrysoperla, Lady bird beetle, Dragon and Damsel flies, Praying mantis,
staphylenids, Predatory ants, bugs & wasps are helpfiil to suppress the white fly population.
The predators viz., Chilomenes sexmaculatus and Chrysoperla carnea offer significant control
of the early season pests.

Use of yellow sticky traps @ 40 per acre during initial phase of the cotton crop to check the
early infestation of whitefly,

Use of 5% Neem Seed Kemal Extract (NSKE) against white fly.

Azadirachtin 0.15%, (Neem Seed Kernel Based EC) @ 2.5-5.0 la.i per ha in 500-1000 litres of
water or Azadirachtin 05.00% w/w Min. Neem Extract Concentrates in 750 litres of water per
hactare for which waiting period is 5 days could be used against thrips and whitefly.
Verticillium lecanii 1.15%WP Strain - AS MEGH-VL Accession No- MCC-1028 (containing
1x 10° CFU/gm) could be used @ 2.5 kg/ha in 500 litres of water against whiteflies.

Pesticides must be used as per label claim approved by the Registration Committee. Detailed
information is available on Directorate’s website in the link http://ppqs. gov. in/divisions/cib-
rc/major-uses-of-pesticides. A list of recommended pesticides for thrips of cotton is attached at
Annexure-I and whitefly of cotton is attached at Annexure-II.

farmers \

pest status. ‘i

Surveillance e and Advisory Unit may be conducted

media, Kisan Gosthi, leaflet and pamphlets.

The detailed information on pest incidence may also be sent to the directorate through email

Sub: Advisory on Pink Boll worm (Pectinophora gossypiella) on cotton crop -reg.

Si:

It is to bring to your notice that incidence of Pink boll worm is reported above
ETL (in an area of three acre) at Khuian Sarwar village of Fazilka district of Punjab
during regular surveys carried out by CIPMC Jalandhar. However, there is possibility
that this pest may cause problem to other cotton growing states Haryana and Rajasthan
also.

Si:

It is to bring to your notice that incidence of Pink boll worm is reported above
ETL (in an area of three acre) at Khuian Sarwar village of Fazilka district of Punjab
during regular surveys carried out by CIPMC Jalandhar. However, there is possibility
that this pest may cause problem to other cotton growing states Haryana and Rajasthan
also. Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing weather condition
population of this pests is expected to flare up.Therefore, cotton crop should be
monitored regularly for pest build up and adopt Integrated Pest Management
techniques. AESA based IPM Package of practices of cotton and pest specific package
of practices of Pink Boll Worm is available at DPPQ&S website in the link
http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages.Important IPM practices are listed below

 

Pink Boll worm:

Infested crop residues should be removed and destructed promptly & the egg and
larvae should be collected and destroyed.

Farmers must be advised to maintain field sanitation at the vicinity of the main field and
nearby areas must be kept free from weeds.

Conserve and augment natural enemies of pink bollworm includes

Parasitoids- Trichogramma brasiliensis (egg), Chelonus sp. (egg-larval), Campoletis
chlorideae (larval), Bracon sp.(larval) etc.

Predators- Chrysoperla carnea, Coccinellids, Reduviid bug, Pentatomid bug
Trichogramma parasitoids may be released directly or Tricho-card can be pinned to the
leaves of standing cotton plants in the fields for destroying the egg stage of PBW.

One spray of neem seed kernel extract (NSKE) 5% may be taken up at 60 days after
sowing

Use of neem based pesticides (Annexure-I) in the initial stage of the pest for
augmentation and conservation of potential parasitioids and predators.

Use PB rope L Phermone traps (140 mg of a.i /dispensar & 9875 dispensars to be used
for 25 ha of area) for the control of adult male moths.

Pesticides must be used as per label claim approved by the registration committee.
Detailed information is available on _ directorate’s website at link
https://ppqs.gov.in/sites/default/files/1. major _use_of pesticides insecticides as on 0
1.06.2023.pdf A list of recommended pesticides for pink boll worm is attached at
Annexure-I.

Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth, Rahuri vide Out No. Cotton/833/2019 dated 20.09.2019, FAW has been reported for the first
time in India on Cotton.

This is the first record of FAW on Cotton in India invaded from infested maize crop, So it is necessary to be
alert about the infestation of FA W in Maharashtra and create awareness in the adjoining states: Gujarat, Andhra Pradesh,
Punjab, Karnataka and Telangana state. The following IPM Strategies should be followed for effective management of
the pest.

¢ — Integrated Pest management needs to be promoted by involving important pest management tools.

¢ — Monitoring and surveillance on regular basis and following IPM practices.

¢ — The infested flowers and green bolls of cotton should be promptly removed and destroyed.

¢ Timely management at early instar level by hand collection of egg masses carrying leaves and destroying them with
larvae.

° — Trichogramma parasitoids may be released directly or Tricho-card can be pinned to the leaves of standing cotton
plants in the fields for destroying the egg stage.

¢ — Use of neem based pesticide at initial stage of the pest for augmentation and conservation of potential parasitoids
and predators.

e — Infested crop residues should be removed and destructed promptly.

¢ Use glossy lure pheromone baited traps for the control of adult male moths.

¢ Farmers must be advised to maintain field sanitation at the vicinity of the main field and nearby areas must be kept
free from weeds. :

e Regular training programmes for the extension workers/ pesticide dealers and farmers should be organized for
upgradation of knowledge and skill.

¢ — Pesticides must be used as per label claim approved by the registration committee. ‘

¢ IPM package of practices for cotton need to be promoted the IPM package of practices for cotton can be
downloaded from http://ppqs.gov.in/sites/default/files/cotton.pdf or from http://farmers.gov.in.

e Regular meetings of State Pest Surveillance and advisory unit and District Pest Surveillance and Advisory Unit may
be conducted,

¢ As recommended from CICR, Nagpur, entomopathogenic fungi Metarhizium anisopliae @ 5g or Nomuraea rileyi
@ 5g per litre of water may be sprayed on cotton crop.

¢ As recommended from CICR, Nagpur, Spinetoram 11.7 SC @ 0.8 ml or Chlorantraniliprole 18.5 SC @ 0.3 ml per
litre of water can be sprayed to already infested cotton crop to avoid further damage. Emamectin Benzoate 5% SG
& 1.9%EC (approved pesticides for Pink Boll Worm (PBW) on Cotton) may also be used for the management of
FAW in cotton.

The hot spot of FA W should be identified for survey and teams may be constituted for regular surveillance and
monitoring of FAW situation. Need based plant protection measures should be adopted to avoid economic loss to the
cotton crop. Timely supply of quality pesticides / bio-pesticides for the control of FAW on Cotton should be ensured.

In view of the above, it is requested to monitor the cotton crop on regular basis and if major incidence of FAW
is reported by the farmers, extension functionaries and even through newspapers or other sources, survey of the affected
may be conducted immediately and the concerned officials at the district/ division/ block may be advised to take the
suitable plant protection measures immediately. The detailed information may also be sent to the Directorate through
email ppa@nic.in urgently to apprise the same to Department of Agriculture, Cooperation & Farmers Welfare.

Yours faithfully

(Rajesh Malik)

Sir,

I have the honor to bring to your notice that the incidence of Pink boll worm is
reported at trace intensity from various parts of the cotton growing areas especially few
districts of Punjab & Karnataka and Whitefly at low to moderate intensity in various
districts of Punjab, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, Rajastan & Tamil Nadu, keeping in view the
current crop stage and prevailing weather conditions population of these pests are
expected to flare up .

Sir,

I have the honor to bring to your notice that the incidence of Pink boll worm is
reported at trace intensity from various parts of the cotton growing areas especially few
districts of Punjab & Karnataka and Whitefly at low to moderate intensity in various
districts of Punjab, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, Rajastan & Tamil Nadu, keeping in view the
current crop stage and prevailing weather conditions population of these pests are
expected to flare up . Therefore, cotton crop should be monitored regularly for pest build
up and adopt Integrated Pest Management techniques. AESA based IPM Package of
practices of cotton and pest specific package of practices of Pink Boll Worm and White fly
are available at DPPQ&S website in the link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages .Important
IPM practices are listed below

Pink Boll worm:

e Deep summer ploughing to expose the pupa to birds and sunlight

e Infested crop residues should be removed and destructed promptly & the
egg masses and larvae should be collected and destroyed.

e Farmers must be advised to maintain field sanitation at the vicinity of the main
field and nearby areas must be kept free from weeds.

e Take up sowing in the month of June with early maturing short duration Bt
cotton hybrid/ varieties recommended for particular region

e Refuge (20 % non Bt seeds) should be plantéd along with Bt cotton, if provided
in separate packet

e Conserve and augment natural enemies of pink bollworm includes

e Parasitoids- Trichogramma brasiliensis (egg), Chelonus sp. (egg-larval),
Campoletis chlorideae (larval), Bracon lefroyi (larval)

e Predators- Chrysoperla carnea, Coccinellids, Reduviid bug, Pentatomid bug

e Trichogramma parasitoids may be released directly or Tricho-card can be
pinned to the leaves of standing cotton plants in the fields for destroying the egg
stage of PBW.

e One-spray of neem seed kernel extract (NSKE) 5% may be taken up at 60 days
after sowing which provides anti feedant and ovicidal effect

e Use of neem based pesticides ( Mentioned in Annexure-I) in the initial stage of
the pest for augmentation and conservation of potential parasitioids and
predators.

e Use PB rope L Phermone traps ( 140 mg of a.i /dispensar & 9875 dispensars to

e Pesticides must be used as per label claim approved by the registration

White Fly <

e Set up yellow sticky traps @ 40 per acre to monitor white fly population.

e Farmers must be educated to identify, conserve and augment the natural enemies
available in the cotton fields like Parasitoides like Encarsia formosa, Encarsia
sp., Eretmocerus mundus and predators like Geocoris sp., Zelus sp. Spiders,
Syrphid fly, Chrysoperla, Lady bird beetle, Dragon and Damsel flies, Praying
mantis, Predatory ants, bugs & wasps which is helpful to suppress the white fly
population.

e Spray Homemade Neem Extract @ 2.5 I/ha against white fly. It can be prepared
by boiling 4 kg terminal parts of the shoots of neem tree including leaves, green
branches and fruits in 10 litre of water for 30 minutes and then filter this material
through muslin cloth and use the filtrate for spraying at recommended dose

e Verticillium lecanii 1.15%WP Strain - AS MEGH-VL Accession No — MCC-
1028 (Containing 1 x10°CFU/gram) could be used @ 2.5 kg/ha in 500 litre of
water against white flies.

e Azadirachtin 0.15%, (Neem Seed Kernel Based EC) @ 2.5-5.0 | ai per ha in
500-1000 litres of water for which waiting period is 5 days.

e Pesticide must be used as per label claim approval by the Registration
Committee. Detailed information is available at directorate website..However,
list of recommended pesticides for cotton whitefly is attached at Annexure-II

Further the following strategies should be adopted for spreading awareness
among farmers

e Mobilization of extension functionaries at grass route level for regular
monitoring of pest status.

e Awareness among farming community through newspapers, printing and
electronic media , KisanGosthi, leaflet and pamphlets.

e The concerned officials at the district/ division/ block level may be advised to
take the suitable plant protection measures immediately

The detailed information on pest incidence may also be sent to the directorate through

email ppa@nic.in or appa.ipm-dppqs@gov.in urgently to apprise the same to Department
of Agriculture & Farmers’ Welfare.

Sub: Advisory on sucking pests of cotton crop -reg.

Sir,

I have the honor to bring to your notice that sucking pests of cotton viz., jassids (Amrasca
biguttula biguttula), aphids (Aphis gossypii), whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci) and thrips, (Thrips tabaci)
are major pests in cotton crop. Some times mites, mealy bug (Phenacoccus solenopsis), red cotton
bug (Dysdercus cingulatus), are also responsible for yield loss if population attain ETL level. Various
sucking pests directly feed on the tender leaves and cause damage to the host, and plant becomes
stunted, distorted, yellowish and show reduced strength and premature leaf loss apart from
transmitting disease organisms. Keeping in view the current crop stage and prevailing weather
conditions population of these pests are expected to increase . Therefore, cotton crop should be
monitored regularly for pest build up and adopt Integrated Pest Management techniques. Agro
Ecosystem Analysis (AESA) based IPM Package of practices of cotton are available at DPPQ&S
website in the link http://ppqs.gov.in/ipm-packages .Important IPM practices for management of
sucking pests are listed below

e Regular surveillance on host crops including alternate hosts such as brinjal, cucurbits,
cucumbers, long melon, Pumpkin, tomato, chilli, okra should be carried out for timely
management of sucking pests.

e Eradicate alternate weed host like Parthenium, Sida sp., Abutilon indicum, Datura metel,
Xanthium sp, etc. to check the multiplication of sucking pests in off season.

© Grow less preferred host crops like Maize, Bajra, Jowar and Dhecha. etc. surrounding to the
cotton field.

e Balanced use of fertilizers & optimum use of irrigation for overall crop pest and
disease management

e Farmers must be educated to identify, conserve and augment the natural enemies available in
the cotton fields parasitoides like Eretmocerus mundus, Encarsia formosa.,and predators like
Spiders, Syrphid fly, Chrysoperla, Lady bird beetle, Dragon and Damsel flies, Praying mantis,
staphylenids, Predatory ants, bugs & wasps are helpful to suppress the white fly population.

e The predators viz., Chilomenes sexmaculatus and Chrysoperla carnea offer significant
control of the early season sucking pests. A predatory prey ratio of 1.5 in respect of jassids
and 0.1 for aphids was found optimal for natural control in presence of coccinellids and
chrysopids.

e Use of yellow sticky traps @ 40 per acre during initial phase of the cotton crop to check the
early infestation of sucking pests.

e The predators viz., Chilomenes sexmaculatus and Chrysoperla carnea offer significant
control of the early season sucking pests. A predatory prey ratio of 1.5 in respect of jassids
and 0.1 for aphids was found optimal for natural control in presence of coccinellids and
chrysopids.

e Use of yellow sticky traps @ 40 per acre during initial phase of the cotton crop to check the
early infestation of sucking pests.

e Use of 5% Neem Seed Kernal Extract (NSKE) against white fly.

Sub: Advisory on current Status of Thrips (Thrips tabaci) for Cotton growing areas of
Gujarat -reg.

Sir,

I have the honour to bring your kind notice that the incidence of Thrips on cotton crop
was found at Low to Moderate level in Vadodara, Anand, Kheda, Bharuch, Narmada, Botad,
Amreli, Surendra Nagar and Gandhinagar districts of Gujarat.

Keeping in view of the severity of the pest, it is advised that the all Cotton growing
areas of Gujarat state may be intensively monitored during Rapid Roving Survey for
assessment of population of Thrips. Therefore, strong linkage among State Agriculture
Department, State Agricultural University, ICAR Institutes and farmers to implement
Integrated Pest Management (IPM) at village level need to be developed.

The following practices of IPM strategies may be followed for management of Thrips on
Cotton crop

1. Grow attractant plants such as French bean to reduce Thrips infestation.

2.

Sir,

I have the honour to bring your kind notice that the incidence of Thrips on cotton crop
was found at Low to Moderate level in Vadodara, Anand, Kheda, Bharuch, Narmada, Botad,
Amreli, Surendra Nagar and Gandhinagar districts of Gujarat.

Keeping in view of the severity of the pest, it is advised that the all Cotton growing
areas of Gujarat state may be intensively monitored during Rapid Roving Survey for
assessment of population of Thrips. Therefore, strong linkage among State Agriculture
Department, State Agricultural University, ICAR Institutes and farmers to implement
Integrated Pest Management (IPM) at village level need to be developed.

The following practices of IPM strategies may be followed for management of Thrips on
Cotton crop

1. Grow attractant plants such as French bean to reduce Thrips infestation.

2. Conserve and augment natural enemy population such as Predatory mite (Amblyseius

.  swirskii), predatory thrips (Aeolothrips sp.), Insidious flower bugs (Orius insidiosus).

3. A strong and foolproof quality control system for fertilizers, bio-fertilizers, pesticides & bio
pesticides needs to be enforced. A special campaign may be launched for quality control of
fertilizers, bio-fertilizers, pesticides & bio-pesticides.
 
4. Regular training programme for the extension workers, pesticide dealers and farmers should
organized by the SAUs/ICAR institutes/CIPMCs/ KVKs for up-gradation of their knowledge
and skill regarding management of Thrips.

5. Insecticides must be used as per label claim approved by the Central Insecticides Board and
Registration Committee detailed information is available at http://ppqs.gov.in/divisions/cib-
rc/major-uses-of-pesticides. However, list of recommended pesticides for Thrips is attached.
(Annexure-I)

6. IPM package of practices for Cotton need to be promoted. The IPM package of practise for
Sugarcane may be downloaded from web-link
http://ppqs.gov.in/sites/default/files/cotton.pdf.

In view of the above, it is advised to undertake monitoring of cotton crop on regular
basis and if any more incidence of Thrips is reported by the farmers, extension functionaries
and even through the newspapers or other source, survey of the affected area may be
conducted immediately and the concermed officials at the Division/District/Block may be
advised to take suitable plant protection measures immediately. The detailed status report
may be sent to this Directorate through Fax (Nos. 0129-2412125 or 011-23384182) or e-

IPM Package of Practices for Management of Rice Swarming Caterpillar  
Rice swarming caterpillar  (Spodoptera mauritia ) or armyworm, is considered 
to be a sporadic pest which occasionally causes serious losses to rice crop. The insect 
is polyphagous in natur e and infests various graminaceous crops and weeds , whereas 
upland rice is its preferred host.  During the last few years it has emerged as a major 
pest in eastern India and caused severe losses to wet season rice production. In Assam, 
the swarming caterpil lars appearance in winter paddy was first reported from Nalbari 
district during first week of September’ 2016. Within short time, pest appearance was 
reported from 27 districts of the state, causing epidemic form creating alarming and 
havoc situation among  the farming community  of the state. Pests history shows 
several times epidemic in Assam during 1967 and 2016 on rice crop.  
Major states affected : Assam, Tripura, Meghalaya, Sikkim  
Damage symptoms/ Incidence/ Behaviour : 
Assam has different physiographic and climatic conditions which results in 
three distinct growing seasons of rice viz, Ahu ( Feb/March -June/July ), Sali (June/July -
Nov/Dec) and Boro (Nov/Dec -May/June). Whereas, i n the year 2016, Sali paddy 
damage by S. mauritia  was counted to be 56,768  ha in  27 districts of Assam with 
major infestations at Golaghat, Sivsagar,  Dibrugarh,  Jorhat,   Barpeta, Nalbari, 
Lakhimpur,  kokrajhar, Majuli,Dhubri, Mongoldoi, Udalguri etc.  
 
 
 
 
The swarming caterpillars damage the paddy crop by cutting off leaf tips, leaf 
margins, leaves and even the plants at the base, more severely on the seedlings in 
nursery and direct seeded crops and early tillering stage in transplanted rice. Newly 
hatched larvae cause the plants to look sick with withered tips and cut leaves. They 
appe ar suddenly in masses and move like an army from field to field so that , fields 
look as if grazed by cattle, warranting to re -sowing or replanting. Whereas, the 
Mythimna separate  attacks the ear heads of the crop  during panicle initiation stage.  
HOST RANG E 
Swarming caterpillar attacks a wide range of graminaceous plant species. Rice 
is the main host of S. mauritia . This pest, in general, breeds on other hosts like 
different kinds of grasses and occasionally on maize, oat and sorghum.  
 
 OCCURRENCE AND PEST OUTBREAKS : 
 
Although the pest has been recorded year round in cropped areas yet it  occurs 
in high numbers only during August to October . This pest occurs in all rice  
environments but is least abundant in irrigated fields. This is essentially a seedling  
pest and rarely infests a crop more than 6 -7 weeks after transplanting. Infestation  
starts at the onset of monsoon. Seedlings of 2 -20 days old in poorly drained fields  
suffer most serious attacks. Direct seeded crops at early stage are seriously attacked  
and in certain cases the entire fields are devastated and needs  re-sowing.  The larvae 
are generally found on crops which are less than 20 -25 days old.  
 The damage to crop becomes  evident from the third instar of the  caterpillar. The 
grown up  caterpillars feed  voraciously by  night devouring the entire plant and  hide 
during the day time. Later in  the season they migrate from older  rice fields to grassy 
areas where  subsequent broods cause severe  damage. Their migration is  facilitated by 
the absence of the  standin g water in the fields. The  larvae suffer high mortality from  
heavy rains and are victims of various bacterial diseases, parasites and predators.  The 
inability of larvae to swim is a weakness. In flooded fields they are forced to stay  on 
the plants which th ey defoliate. They are thus exposed to birds and other predators.  
Outbreaks occur after a period of prolonged drought followed by heavy rain.  
Drought kills their natural enemies and flooding allows S. mauritia larvae to 
concentrate  on rice plants.

during the day time. Later in  the season they migrate from older  rice fields to grassy 
areas where  subsequent broods cause severe  damage. Their migration is  facilitated by 
the absence of the  standin g water in the fields. The  larvae suffer high mortality from  
heavy rains and are victims of various bacterial diseases, parasites and predators.  The 
inability of larvae to swim is a weakness. In flooded fields they are forced to stay  on 
the plants which th ey defoliate. They are thus exposed to birds and other predators.  
Outbreaks occur after a period of prolonged drought followed by heavy rain.  
Drought kills their natural enemies and flooding allows S. mauritia larvae to 
concentrate  on rice plants. Outbreak s of this pest are more common in broadcasted 
rice sown in  ill-drained soils . 
 
Factors favouring population build -up: 
 Prolonged dry condition followed by heavy rainfall favours its outbreak.  
 Excessive application of Nitrogenous fertilizers.   Wind and rain s torm helps in migration of moths to long distances.  
 Pest occurs throughout the year on alternate hosts and move to paddy in kharif 
season.  
 Heavy rainfall leads to high mortality of larval population.  
 Pest migrates from older rice to grassy areas for off se ason survival.  
IDENTIFICATION : 
As per the University studies, two species, viz. Are observed in Assam.  
The larvae are described to differentiate the several armyworm species from each 
other:  
1. Rice swarming caterpillar or grass armyworm ( Spodoptera 
mauritia ):  
Mature larvae are 3.8 -4 cm long and are green, grey, or brown 
in colour with dark dull dorsal and sub dorsal longitudinal 
stripes.  Two rows of C -shaped black spots are visible along the 
backs.  
 
2. Paddy armyworm, true armyworm ( Mythimna separata ):  
Matur e larvae are 3 -4 cm long, green to pink in colour and 
provided with longitudinal light grey to black stripes running 
along the entire  length of their bodies. Head is brown to orange with 
an A -marking.  
 
LIFE CYCLE : The life cycle of this pest is completed i n 25 to 40 days with suitable 
temperature and humidity , through eggs, larvae/caterpillars, pupae and adults. It 
completes 3 -4 generations in a year.   
Eggs : A single female generally lays 5 -6 oblong egg masses each containing 150 -200 eggs at 
the tips of upr ight leaves. Eggs ar e covered with gray hairs/setae. An egg is  spherical and 
creamy in colour when laid  and acquires a brown tinge as  development proceeds.  
Larvae : Hatching usually occurs during the  morning hours. The newly hatched  larvae are 
very active a nd feed by  scraping the green matter from the leaf  tips. The newly 
hatched/young larvae/caterpillars are light green  with yellowish white lateral and dorsal  
stripes and are about 2 mm in length . As the caterpillars grow, they  become greyish brown 
with a cr escent  shaped black spot on the side of each  segment.  When disturbed, larva curls 
into a ring which is a characteristic  common to all cut worms and armyworms . 
Pupae : For pupation the mature larvae burrows  in the soil to find a suitable place for  
pupation. Pupation takes place in the soil in  an earthen cell slightly below the ground  level.  
Adults: The adult is stout built, dark brown moth measuring about 15 -20 mm in 
length and 30 -40 mm in wing expanse. Forewings of female moth are greyish brown 
with wavy lin es and a dark spot sub centrally. Male moth has immense tufts of hairs 
on the forelegs. Wings of the male moth are more greyish. The hind wings are 
brownish white with thin black margins. The moths are nocturnal and hide in the 
crevices in soils or under v egetation during day time. The adult moths are strong fliers 
and move long distances for oviposition.

and move long distances for oviposition.

INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT  STRATEGIES:  
 All stake holders like  State Agriculture Department, State Agricultural 
University, Research Institutes and farmers to implement Integrated Pest Management 
(IPM)  as social movement to implement in compatible manner to manage the pest by 
adopting preventive, monitoring and interc eptive measures  at village level.  
Pest Monitoring  
Monitoring of the pest is an important component of IPM for identifying the 
hot spots at early stage. The monitoring can be done by survey and surveillance by 
employing scouts or progressive farmers. The p est can be managed by spot 
application or with low doses of insecticides without adversely affecting the 
environment at early stage. As the pest appears in Spetember , therefore, the 
monitoring is to be initiated by month of July to August . The population c an be 
confirmed by digging the soil up to 6 -9 inches , where the S. mauritia larvae burrow 
for pupation. As the moths are attracted towards light, therefore, the light trap can also 
be utilized as an important tool for monitoring the moth population. Number  of moths 
attracted towards the light will give an indication about the severely of the pest.  
a. Cultural control  
 Crop ro tation in endemic pockets helps  
 Deep  ploughing the field in summer exposes the larvae and pupae for predation 
by birds \ 
 Remove of exces s nurseries and weeds from the field and bunds.  
  Flooding the nurseries and paddy fields brings out the larvae to the surface, 
which get predated  by the birds.  
  Herd of ducks if let in to the field, will feeds on the caterpillars . 
  Use of bamboo perches fa cilitates predation by birds.  
  In case of severe infestation, small plots can be isolated and the movement of 
the   caterpillars can be prevented by digging a trench around the infested field 
wherever possible.  
  Practice of mud plastering of field bunds.  
 
 b. Mechanical  
 The inability of S. mauritia larvae to swim in water is a weakness and in 
flooded fields they are forced to stay on the plants which they defoliate. 
Therefore, kerosene oil may be poured into the stagnant water in the bunded 
fields (2 L kero sene per hectare). With the use of a long rope stretched across 
the field (two persons walk through the field) the paddy plants are shaken 
rigorously. The larvae fall into the kerosenized water and ultimately die.  
 Application of malathion dust ( 5% dust app lied at 25 kg ha –1) or chlorpyriphos 
dust (1.5%) along the bunds of the field kills the pest and also prevents the 
migration of larvae to other rice fields. The technique was widely adopted 
because it proved to be a cheap and effective method for managing the S. 
mauritia within a short time.  
 Before the paddy season, grasses near the fields earmarked for paddy, may be 
destroyed mechanically which provide shelter and act as reservoir for migration 
of larvae.  
 As the moths of S. mauritia are attracted towards light, therefore, light traps 
can also be utilized for mass trapping of the moths.

dust (1.5%) along the bunds of the field kills the pest and also prevents the

can also be utilized for mass trapping of the moths.  
 
c.  Biological control : 
Parasites/parasitoids : 
Under natural conditions, the egg parasitoids have been found effective in 
containing the population of S. mauritia.  Parasitizat ion of S. mauritia  egg masses by 
Telenomus  spp. ranged from 80 -90%. A number of larval parasites viz. Apanteles spp., 
Meterorus  spp, Charops  bicolour, C. dominans , Charop  spp have been reported. A 
braconid, Apanteles , a solitary internal larval parasite ov iposit on the minute first 
instar caterpillars although it could also parasitize second and third instar larvae.  
 
Predators : 
The vertebrate predators such a s the common crow, the cattle e gret, the paddy 
bird, the white breasted water hen and the mynah,  have also been found to predate on 
the larvae of this pest.  
 
 d. Chemical control : 
 Spray of chlorpyriphos 20 EC @ 2.5 litres/ha or quinalphos 25 EC @2.0 
litres/ha or triazophos 40 EC @ 1.0 litres/ha or Dichlorvos 76 SL 600 ml/ha on 
the paddy crop during evening  hours . 
 Dusting of chlorpyriphos 1.5 % D powder controls this pest.  
 Spraying at early stage is very effective .

IPM Package of Practices for Management of White fly Bemisia tabaci  in cotton  
 
Cotton is a major commercial cash crop of India provide s raw material to textile 
industry. The c rop is attacked by many sucking pest such as  White fly, Jassid, Mealy bug 
and Mit es. Among them whitefly  is a serious pest .  In recent years after introduction of Bt 
cotton White  fly has become an economically important pest and causing severe yield 
loss in agricultural, horticulture and in ornamental crops.  
 It is considered as most i mportant pest in its  economic point of view due to its 
high rate of population build -up, mobility, polyphagy nature and the ability to transmit 
virus vector such as Cotton Leaf Curl Virus (CLCV) and ability to develop black sooty 
mould on leaf.  
Major Stat es affected: Punjab, Haryana   
Nature of damage: Whitefly is polyphagous in nature, feeding on many cultivated and 
uncultivated host plants. It adapts easily on new host plants and become a serious pest 
some of the  field crops like cotton, moong, cucurbits tomato, potato okra and brinjal  are 
severely infested by Whitefly.  
White fly prefers  young leaves , they direct feed on the tender leaves and damage  
by piercing and sucking cell sap. This feeding causes leaf chlorosis, leaf withering, and 
premature dropping  of boll & leaves  which  ultimately leads the plant to death.  Indirectly 
they also  decrease the yield  by excreting  honeydew like material . This honeydew serves 
as a substrate for the growth of blac k sooty mold on leaves and boll surface which 
impede photosy nthesis . The third type of damage is by acting as a vecto r for dreadful 
plant viruses. A small population of whiteflies is sufficient to cause CLCV disease.      
Population of Whitefly in Cotton  
Identification of the pest:  
Eggs:  Eggs are yellowish white la id singly on the under surface of leaves. They are 
stalked and sub elliptical in shape.  
Nymphs:  Nymphs are yellowish and brownish, sub elliptical and scale like. They are 
found in large numbers on underside of leaves.  
Pupae:  Pupae also resemble same as n ymphs in shape and have brownish opercula.  
Adults:  Adults are tiny and white in colour. They have a yellow body dusted lightly with 
a white waxy powder.  
 Females: Females are 1.1 –1.2 mm long; Antennae of females are longer than 
males  
 Males: Males are sligh tly smaller; Parameres of males are extended, narrow and 
pointed .  
Economic Threshold Levels (ETL): Whiteflies 6 adults per leaf upper canopy of plants 
or more than 10 whiteflies found in middle region of the plant in >50% (two out of four) 
of plants. Flig ht of adults producing a smoky appearance when plants are shaken mildly  
 
Management practices:  
 
A. Pre-sowing operations  
1. Select only recommended and early maturing hybrid varieties which are 
resistant against whitefly.  2. Late maturing varieties should not be chosen  to avoid damage of white fly.  
3. Regular surveillance on alternate host crops like brinjal, cucurbits, cucumbers, 
long melon, Pumpkin, tomato, chilli, okra from February onwards should be 
carried out for timely management of  white fly . 
4. Eradicate altern ate weed host like Parthenium , Kanghi buti ( Sida sp .), Peeli 
buti ( Abutilon indicum )), Datura metel , Gutputna ( Xanthium sp. ), Puthkanda, 
Bhakra, Itsit, and Tandla should be removed to check the multiplic ation of 
white fly in off season . 
B. Sowing operation  
1. Grow only recommended Bt cotton cultivars  
2. Timely sowing from 1st April to15th May 
3. Adopt recommended spacing of 67.5 x 75 cm and ensure to grow special line 
of refusal cotton plant as a safe guard for maintain Bt resistance against Boll 
Worm complex.  
4. Avoid in tercropping like cucumber, okra, summer Moong, and other cucurbits 
and malvacious crop.

4. Eradicate altern ate weed host like Parthenium , Kanghi buti ( Sida sp .), Peeli 
buti ( Abutilon indicum )), Datura metel , Gutputna ( Xanthium sp. ), Puthkanda, 
Bhakra, Itsit, and Tandla should be removed to check the multiplic ation of 
white fly in off season . 
B. Sowing operation  
1. Grow only recommended Bt cotton cultivars  
2. Timely sowing from 1st April to15th May 
3. Adopt recommended spacing of 67.5 x 75 cm and ensure to grow special line 
of refusal cotton plant as a safe guard for maintain Bt resistance against Boll 
Worm complex.  
4. Avoid in tercropping like cucumber, okra, summer Moong, and other cucurbits 
and malvacious crop.  
5. Grow less preferred host crops surrounding the cotton field like Maize,  Bajra, 
Jawar  and Dhecha. etc. 
6. Apply recommended dose of fertilizers (N, P) on the basis of soil t esting 
report.  
7. Apply Muriate of Potash (MoP) @ 20 kg per acre which helpful to manage the 
bio stress tolerance of crop.  
8.  Judicious and timely application of water is essential during vegetative and 
flowering phases of cotton crop to maintain proper vigour of plant. Excessive 
irrigation usually promotes vegetative growth that is conducive for build up of 
white fly.    
C. Vegetative Phase  
1. Regular field monitoring and surveillance of the cotton field April onward 
should be carried out to take appropriate action for timely management.  2. Special attention required for surveillance where cotton crop is in the vicinity 
of Kinnow orchards.  
3. Apply spray of Potassium nitrate (NPK 13:0:45) @ 2 kg/acre at for tnight ly 
interval starting from s quare initiation stage which is helpful to manage the 
flower and boll dropping problems.  
4. Farmers must be educated to identify, conserve and augment the natural 
enemies  available in the cotton fields  like Parasitoide s like Encarsia formosa , 
Encarsia shafeei , Encarsia sp ., Eretmocerus mund us and predators like 
Geocoris sp., Zelus sp . Spiders, Syrphid fly, Chrysoperla , Lady bird beetle, 
Dragon and Damsel flies, Praying mantis, Predatory ants, bugs & wasps which 
is helpful to suppress the white fly population.  
5. Use low cost yellow sticky traps  @ 40 per acre during initial phase of the 
cotton crop to check the early infestation of whitefly.  
6. Proper clean cultivation of crop should be maintained weed free for at least 8 -9 
weeks after sowing till canopy starts closing in by timely inter -culture  for 
better  plant health . 
7. Azadirachtin 0.15%, (Neem Seed Kernel Based EC) @ 2.5 -5.0 l/ha 
Azadirachtin 0.03% (300ppm) (Neem Oil Based WSP) @ 2.5 -5.0 l/ha against  
whiteflies  
8. Spray Home made Neem Extract @ 2.5 l/ha against white fly.  
Method of Preparation:  
Boil 4 kg terminal parts of the shoots of neem tree including leaves, green 
branches and fruits in 10 litre of water for 30 minutes and then filter this 
material through muslin cloth and use the filtrate for spraying at recommended 
dose.  
9. Verticillium lecanii  1.15%WP is recommended @ 2.5 kg/ha in 500 litre  of 
water against white flies.  
 D. Reproductive phase  
1. Monitor the crop regularly  
2. Avoid using synthetic pyrethroids viz. Cypermethrin , Deltamethrin,  Fenvalate, 
Acephate and Acetamiprid to minimise resurgence of wh ite fly.  
3. Spray chemical insecticides when the population of whitefly has crossed to 
ETL level i.e.  6 adults per leaf upper canopy of plants before 10 a.m.

Note: 1. Rotation of chemical groups helps in preventing the build up of 
resistance against insecticides.  
2. When adult population is low and nymph pop ulation on the under 
surface of leaves is high or occurrence of honeydew symptoms appear on 
upper/lower surface the plant leaves then spray Pyriproxyfen 10 EC @  500

3. In case of severe infestation of whitefly adults, spray Flonicam id 50 WG
